news.title: Mnangagwa Hands Over Power
news.content:
By A Correspondent  Zimbabwe has handed over the Chairmanship of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) Council of Ministers to Madagascar, marking the end of its term at the helm of the regional policy-making body.

The Council is meeting from 1214 August 2025 in Antananarivo, Madagascar, to deliberate on programmes and policies aimed at deepening regional integration, strengthening peace and security, and driving economic growth.

The gathering sets the stage for the 45th SADC Summit of Heads of State and Government on 17 August, where final decisions will be endorsed. This years summit theme is:Advancing Industrialisation, Agricultural Transformation, and Energy Transition for a Resilient SADC.

Zimbabwes Minister of International Relations and Trade, Amon Murwira, formally passed the chairmanship to Madagascars Foreign Affairs Minister, Rafaravavitafika Rasata, during a ceremony on Tuesday.

Over the three-day session, ministers are reviewing progress on the SADC Regional Indicative Strategic Development Plan (20202030), assessing institutional reports, and taking key decisions on industrialisation, infrastructure, food security, energy, and peace in the region.

Murwira urged member states to accelerate the ratification and implementation of SADC protocols and agreements, warning that delays undermine the blocs shared vision.

A key impediment to advancing our regional integration agenda is our slow uptake of SADC Protocols and Agreements. This delay is not just a procedural concern; it strikes at the very heart of our shared vision for a united, prosperous, and resilient region, he said.

Murwira commended Rasatas appointment, pledged Zimbabwes full support, and encouraged other member states to rally behind Madagascars leadership.

In her acceptance remarks, Rasata thanked SADC members for their trust and pledged to prioritise the inclusion of island states in the regional agenda.

SADC is an essential pillar of regional cooperation and solidarity, on which we can rely to jointly address our challenges and seize the opportunities before us, she said.By uniting the maritime, economic, environmental, and cultural potential of the islands with the resources, agricultural strength, and industrial capacity of our continental states, we can build the self-reliant and competitive SADC we aspire to.

The Councils resolutions will feed into the 45th SADC Summit, where regional leaders are expected to map out strategies for a stronger, more united, and prosperous Southern Africa.

news.title: International Football Returns To Zim As National Sports Stadium Gets Partial CAF Approval
news.content:
Sports Correspondent

The Confederation of African Football (CAF) has officially approved the National Sports Stadium in Harare, signaling a major step forward for the revival of international football in Zimbabwe.

After more than four years without hosting an international fixture due to all local venues being condemned by CAF, the landmark approval brings hope for a renewed presence on the continental stage.

The National Sports Stadium has undergone extensive renovations, earning it special clearance to host Category 2 international matches. This approval permits the venue to stage preliminary round games in the CAF Champions League and CAF Confederation Cup, along with qualifiers for the U23, U20, and U17 Africa Cup of Nations (Afcon) tournaments.

This development means Simba Bhora can return to the stadium for their upcoming clash against Nsingizi Hotspurs in September. However, CAF has not yet given the green light for the senior mens and womens national teams to play at the venue.

The Warriors must continue to wait, as the stadiums renovations have yet to meet the stringent standards required for senior international fixtures. Consequently, Zimbabwes national team will play their forthcoming 2026 FIFA World Cup qualifier home matches at Orlando Stadium in Johannesburg.

The CAF approval marks a pivotal milestone, reigniting hopes that Zimbabwe will soon fully reclaim its place as a host of international football on home soil.

news.title: Despite Deepening Economic Crisis, Mnangagwa Boasts of Rising Milk Production
news.content:
By A Correspondent

Speaking at the Heroes Day main commemoration event at the National Heroes Acre in Harare on Monday, President Emmerson Mnangagwa highlighted what he described as significant milestones achieved by his administration despite the worsening economic turmoil facing the country.

Below is the full keynote address delivered by His Excellency, President Emmerson Dambudzo Mnangagwa on 11 August 2025:

KEYNOTE ADDRESS BY HIS EXCELLENCY, PRESIDENT EMMERSON DAMBUDZO MNANGAGWA

Ladies and Gentlemen, Comrades and Friends,

It is my singular honour and privilege to address this 45th Commemoration of our National Heroes Day, an event our nation holds annually in tribute to the gallant sons and daughters of the soil, who paid the supreme sacrifice for the liberation of our country. Theirs was a selfless struggle for the freedom we enjoy today, that must forever remain engraved in our collective conscience.

This emboldens us to resolutely guard our sovereignty as well as fortify our resolve to build a prosperous economy encapsulated in our national Vision 2030. Today, we also honour the living heroes and heroines who continue to epitomize patriotism, loyalty, and commitment to the nation.

The historic feats of our heroes and heroines are an enduring legacy bequeathed to us, which should serve as an inspiration in our march to realise Vision 2030. To immortalise the selfless sacrifices made by our forebears in the struggle for independence, freedom, and democracy, the Second Republic is spearheading various projects across the country.

Sikombela, Hwahwa, Butcher Camp, Dzapasi, and Connemara are among the shrines built by government to preserve our rich liberation war heritage.

During todays celebration, I will confer honours and awards to our living and departed heroes for their outstanding accomplishments. I shall also preside over the investiture of awards of the Highest Order, including the Royal Order of Munhumutapa, Silver Cross of Zimbabwe, and the Robert Mugabe Commendation Award for Service in Human Capital Development.

Independence medals for eligible veterans of the Liberation Struggle will also be conferred across our provinces.

In recognition of the sterling contribution to our national development and unity by members of the public sector, some civil servants will be honoured for their long service to the country.

I call upon all of us to play our part to spur economic growth, employment, and wealth creation opportunities, alongside harmonious and clean communities. The duty to achieve a thriving, industrialised, and prosperous economy lies with all of us.

Nyika inovakwa, inotongwa, inonamatigwa nevene vayo / Ilizwe lakhiwa, libuswe, likhulelwe ngabanikazi balo.

Fellow Zimbabweans,

This 45th Heroes Anniversary allows us to once again take stock of the strides we are making to realise the goals for which many departed and living heroes and heroines waged the protracted struggle. Independence in 1980 brought political independence, but the struggle for economic independence continues.

We have much to be proud of as the people of this great motherland, Zimbabwe. We are masters of our own destiny, a proud independent, sovereign, and empowered African nation. Neo-colonialism will never be given a foothold in our country.

The multi-pronged reform programmes under the Second Republic have shown positive impacts on the economy and the quality of life for citizens. Despite challenges from illegal sanctions, fluctuating international mineral prices, and a volatile global trade environment, our economy is demonstrating resilience.

The national Gross Domestic Product has risen to US$45.7 billion, up from US$16 billion in 2018. Domestic demand growth is pleasing, and the projected 6% economic growth for 2025 remains achievable.

The national fiscus continues to improve its capacity to fund key areas such as agriculture, health, education, social protection, and infrastructure development.

The new land tenure system is set to revolutionise agriculture by enabling farmers to invest in increased production. Transformational impacts are expected regarding financing access, productivity, mechanisation, and infrastructure.

Zimbabwes successes in maize, wheat, traditional grains, record tobacco production, the recovery of the national herd, and increased milk production highlight the hard work and perseverance of our people.

We celebrate farmers and stakeholders in the agricultural sector who continue to be worthy custodians of the land paid for with the precious blood of our heroes and heroines. Our heroes would surely be proud of these strides.

Tinokutendai varimi, nemhuri yose yeZimbabwe, nekuchengetedza nhaka yedu yakarwirwa nemagamba edu, vatiri kuyeuka zuva ranhasi.

Despite ongoing macroeconomic instability and challenges, agro-industries are showing signs of recovery.

Localisation of value chains and beneficiation efforts have led to growth in the manufacturing sector, now contributing 15% to GDP. The Zimbabwe Industrial Reconstruction and Growth Plan and the Local Content Strategy provide opportunities for value addition, job creation, and export growth.

New investments and expansions in manufacturingsuch as iron and steel, cement, and food processingbenefit from a stable business environment.

Mining remains vital to economic development, contributing over 13.3% of GDP and employing millions. Responsible mining, environmental compliance, and respect for cultural values remain priorities.

Efforts to boost energy self-sufficiency are progressing with Independent Power Producers, especially in renewables. Industry-level solar power installations have improved generation capacity.

Modern transport infrastructure remains critical. Projects include upgrades and rehabilitation of national roads, airports, and border posts, such as the Harare-Masvingo-Beitbridge Highway and several key interchanges and bypasses.

Fellow Zimbabweans,

Our heroes bequeathed a legacy of inclusive growth. Government continues to adopt modern approaches to implement high-impact, people-centered projects.

Devolution and decentralisation ensure no one and no place is left behind, with additional resources allocated to local authorities.

Health delivery reforms target Non-Communicable Diseases and improved access to affordable care through better funding and equipped facilities.

Education and skills development anchor industrialisation. The Heritage-Based Curriculum develops talented youththe emerging heroes of tomorrow.

Legislative reforms in education, including the Zimbabwe School Examinations Council Bill and the Teaching Profession Council Bill, are underway.

Vocational and entrepreneurial programmes expand beyond cities, fostering employment and rural industrialisation. Efforts to bridge rural-urban digital divides continue.

Fellow Citizens,

Climate resilience and orderly human settlements remain fundamental. Government addresses dysfunctional settlements and issues title deeds to affected communities.

Tinotenda vose varikuvaka kumaruwa neku madhorobha, zvichisanganisira vana vekwedu variku Diaspora. Citizens, including those in the diaspora, contribute to a housing boom in rural and urban areas, transforming Zimbabwes built environment.

Government will continue comprehensive rural development initiatives, scaling up projects such as borehole drilling, livestock pass-on schemes, solar energy, internet access, and village business units.

Youth, women, and liberation war veterans have embraced these programmes.

The public sector is commended for patriotism, professionalism, and diligence, with a call to continue driving economic growth and quality social services.

State-owned enterprises are urged to improve efficiency and profitability.

Ladies and Gentlemen,

My administration is preserving national historical and cultural heritage, with research on posthumously declared national heroes and updated biographies of early nationalists.

Zimbabwes liberation war was fought with international solidarity, which remains central to our foreign relations, guided by the United Nations Charter.

Zimbabwe has submitted a bid for a non-permanent seat on the UN Security Council for 20272028 and is a founding member of the International Organisation for Mediation.

Later this week, Zimbabwe will hand over the chairmanship of SADC to Madagascar, following a successful term under the theme Promoting Innovation to Unlock Opportunities for Sustained Economic Growth and Development towards an Industrialised SADC.

Comrades and Friends,

Culture, arts, and heritage are integral to a stable and growing economy. Culture centres are being built nationwide to support creative industries.

Youth participation in socio-economic development is a priority, with sports facilities promoting healthy lifestyles and careers.

Traditional institutions and financing initiatives support women entrepreneurs and SMEs.

Sustainable development principles guide resource use for current and future generations.

Zimbabwe hosted important environmental conferences to strengthen national environmental policies.

As climate change impacts worsen, the focus remains on resilience, mitigation, adaptation, and inclusive climate-smart development.

Finally,

As we gather at National Heroes Acre and other sacred sites, let us look to the future with resolve. These commemorations rekindle the spirit of sacrifice embodied by our heroes and heroines.

The baton is now passed to usthe youth, women, and men across rural and urban Zimbabweto build a modern, industrialised nation.

We must not stop at middle-income status or Vision 2030; let us break ceilings and reach beyond horizons.

As todays heroes and heroines, let us pioneer innovations and reach new heights.

The revolutionary spirit that inspired our forebears should unite us, from Limpopo to Zambezi, Plumtree to Mutare, in pursuing unprecedented milestones.

Forward ever, backward never. Success and prosperity are certain.

With these remarks, I wish you all a happy 45th Heroes Day Anniversary Commemoration.

End of Address

news.title: Zanu PF Eyes Victory In Masvingo By-election Amid Growing Fears of Electoral Manipulation
news.content:
By A Correspondent

Emmerson Mnangagwas Zanu PF is determined to secure victory in the Masvingo Urban Ward 7 by-election, but observers warn the ruling party is banking heavily on voter apathy, vote buying, and patronage rather than genuine support.

The by-election, scheduled for September 13 following the passing of Councillor Tafara Masimba, has drawn criticism over the credibility of the electoral process amid widespread concerns of manipulation.

Critics argue that Zanu PFs focus appears to be on exploiting public fatigue and using unfair tactics to maintain control.

However, Zanu PF Masvingo provincial spokesperson Pepukai Chiwewe on Monday said:

I am pleased to confirm that Cde Simbarashe Shonhiwa is our duly elected candidate to represent us in the upcoming Masvingo Urban Constituency Ward 7 by-elections.

The primary elections were conducted in a free, fair, and transparent manner, allowing eligible voters to exercise their right.

Notably, all four participating candidates accepted the results, showcasing a commendable spirit of maturity and party discipline in our internal electoral process. Our united goal is to reclaim Ward 7 for ZANU PF, ably led by His Excellency President Emmerson D. Mnangagwa.

While Chiwewe expressed confidence in the partys preparedness, critics remain unconvinced, pointing to a pattern of electoral malpractice. The ruling partys reliance on vote buying and patronage continues to cast doubt on the fairness of the upcoming by-election.

As the contest approaches, concerns linger over whether voters will be able to freely exercise their choice or if Zanu PFs controversial tactics will dominate once again.

news.title: Chitungwiza Man In Trouble After Being Caught With Mutoriro
news.content:
By A Correspondent

Gilbert Matimura (35) was remanded in custody last week at the Chitungwiza Magistrates Court after being found in possession of 86 sachets of crystal methamphetamine.

The arrest occurred on 7 August 2025 at approximately 1:00 pm in Unit M, Chitungwiza, following a tip-off to police that Matimura was in possession of mutoriro.

Upon arrival, detectives observed his movements before conducting a search of the premises.

During the search, police discovered 86 sachets of crystal methamphetamine and two boxes of plastic wrappers hidden in Matimuras bedroom. The total weight of the drugs was 30 grams, with an estimated street value of USD 300.

news.title: Opposition Leader Blasts Partisan Army on National Defence Forces Day
news.content:
By A Correspondent

Opposition activist Stephen Sarkozy Chuma has accused Zimbabwes military of betraying the people it is meant to protect, saying it has become a partisan force aligned with the ruling ZANU PF party.

In a statement marking Defence Forces Day, Chuma recalled the events of August 1, 2018, when soldiers opened fire on protesters in central Harare, killing several civilians.

On this Defence Forces Day, we are again reminded about how the military butchered unarmed defenseless citizens in the streets of Harare on 01 August 2018, Chuma said.

He condemned what he described as the militarisation of politics and the erosion of professionalism within the army.

We need a professional and non-partisan defence service and not one that operates like ZANU PF thugs, he added.

Chumas remarks come as the role of the military continues to draw scrutiny, with critics alleging that security forces are being used to stifle dissent and protect the political interests of the ruling elite rather than safeguard national security.

news.title: Mnangagwa Boasts Of Economic Gains, But Inflation and Poverty Continue Unabated…
news.content:
By A Correspondent

During the 45th Heroes Day main commemoration event at the National Heroes Acre on Monday, President Emmerson Mnangagwa praised several economic milestones achieved under his leadership, including a GDP increase to US$45.7 billion and projected 6% growth for 2025.

Yet, despite these optimistic figures, many Zimbabweans continue to suffer from soaring inflation, persistent unemployment, and shortages of essential goods  problems the Presidents speech notably failed to address.

Mnangagwa hailed the remarkable resilience of the economy amid external sanctions and global trade challenges, highlighting successes in agriculture, manufacturing, and mining. Zimbabwes success stories in maize, wheat, and tobacco production, along with increased milk yields, are testament to the hard work and perseverance of our people, he said.

However, the lived reality of many Zimbabweans tells a different story. Inflation remains stubbornly high, and the average citizen struggles with rising prices and stagnant incomes. Basic services and infrastructure are still patchy, particularly in rural areas where economic benefits have been slow to reach.

While the President mentioned ongoing reforms and resource allocation to sectors like health and education, critics argue these efforts have yet to translate into meaningful improvements for the majority.

The speech skirted over the growing inequality and economic hardships fueling public discontent.

Mnangagwa called for unity and hard work to achieve Vision 2030s industrialisation goals, but many remain unconvinced. We must boldly decide now, that we will not stop at upper-middle-income status, he said. Yet without concrete plans to tackle inflation and create jobs, this ambitious target risks remaining out of reach.

As Zimbabweans marked Heroes Day reflecting on sacrifice and resilience, the economic struggles at home raise urgent questions about how inclusive and sustainable the governments progress truly is.

news.title: Mnangagwa Honours Jairos Jiri
news.content:
By A Correspondent President Emmerson Mnangagwa has posthumously declared four national heroes and presented national flags to their families during this years Heroes Day commemorations.

The four honoured were human rights and disability rights pioneer Jairos Jiri, Brigadier-General (Retired) Lameck Francisco Mutanda, John Mbedzi, and Elos David Malandu.

Jairos Jiri: A Legacy of ServiceThe late Jairos Jiri is remembered as one of Zimbabwes most selfless humanitarians. Born in 1921 in Bikita District, Masvingo Province, Jiri rose from humble beginnings to become a champion for the welfare of people with disabilities. In 1948, he founded the Jairos Jiri Association, an organisation that transformed the lives of thousands of physically challenged and disadvantaged people through vocational training, education, rehabilitation, and housing.

Jiris work extended far beyond charityhe was instrumental in promoting social inclusion at a time when disability was stigmatised and neglected in colonial Rhodesia. His initiatives, such as workshops, hostels, and training centres across the country, became safe havens for the marginalised. His dedication earned him both national and international recognition, cementing his place as a towering figure in Zimbabwes social development history.

In recent years, however, Jiris family has faced hardship. Earlier this year, his widow made a heartfelt public appeal for assistance, revealing that she was living in poverty despite her late husbands lifelong service to the nation. Her plight touched many Zimbabweans, sparking renewed calls for greater state and community support for the families of national heroes.

Heroes Day CommemorationsHeroes Day remains one of Zimbabwes most significant national events, a time to honour both the living and departed who contributed to the liberation and development of the country.

Upon arrival at the National Heroes Acre, President Mnangagwa inspected a guard of honour mounted by the Presidential Guard. He was joined by Vice President General (Retired) Dr Constantino Chiwenga and Colonel (Retired) Kembo Mohadi in laying wreaths at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

This year, the families of the four newly declared national heroes received national flags in recognition of their loved ones contributions.

Awards for Exceptional ServiceProfessor Vladimir Shubin, former Secretary of the Soviet Afro-Asian Solidarity Committee and Head of the Africa Section of the Communist Party of the Soviet Unions International Department, was presented with the Zimbabwe International Friendship Award for his role in supporting the countrys liberation struggle.

Inasem Chitutu, a teenager from Bindura who courageously rescued two children from a burning house, received the Silver Cross of Zimbabwe.

Dr Madeline Nyamwanzathe first female African medical doctor in Zimbabwewas honoured with the Robert Gabriel Mugabe Commendation Award for Service in Human Capital Development for her pioneering work in healthcare.

These living heroes join more than two thousand veterans of the liberation struggle and outstanding citizens recognised this year.

As the nation celebrates its heroes, President Mnangagwa reminded Zimbabweans that the responsibility to build a prosperous, upper-middle-income society by 2030 rests with every citizen.

news.title: Six Church Members Die In Masvingo Horror Crash
news.content:
By A Correspondent-Six members of the Zion Christian Church were killed in a road traffic accident at the 283-kilometre peg along the Mutare-Masvingo Road on Monday morning.

The accident occurred around 2 AM when a Toyota Quantum carrying the congregants veered off the road, overturned, and landed back on its wheels, leaving 16 others injured.

Zimbabwe Republic Police (ZRP) spokesperson Commissioner Paul Nyathi confirmed the accident in a statement issued Monday afternoon.

The victims bodies were taken to Masvingo General Hospital for postmortem, while the injured were admitted to the same facility.

Nyathi added that the names of the victims will be released once identification by next of kin is complete.

In a separate accident, Nyathi confirmed that one person died and 20 others were injured when a Nissan NP300 with 20 passengers veered off the road and overturned after its left rim broke.

This happened at around 5 AM on 10 August at a bridge along Four Mile Drive near Hwange Colliery Training Centre.

Nyathi urged motorists to avoid speeding and to observe all road safety rules to protect lives.
